I regret nothing! Addictive, grotesque, and hilarious game. Postal Dude is one of the coolest protagonists ever. The crazy achievements you can earn and the different game modes are also definitely an advantage. Apart from the base game, the DLC is also definitely worth your attention and completing it takes even much more time.

Postal 2 (base game):
I think the base game is the coolest, most classic, and offers the most opportunities in free roam to earn achievements. As a fan of Tarantino's films, I appreciate the Pulp Fiction gimp outfit reference in Wednesday.

Apocalypse Weekend (DLC no 1)
The DLC is darker and features zombies and zombie cows. As if the cat apocalypse on Friday wasn't enough... Apocalypse Weekend focuses on fewer core quests. I think it's also more challenging, but also more repetitive. Still, it's fun to play.

Paradise Lost (DLC no 2)
The second DLC is more reminiscent of the original and, despite being 12 years old, is created on the same engine. Free Roam offers more possibilities than the Apocalypse Weekend solution. Zack Ward's performance is an obvious reference to Uwe Ball's film, where Postal Dude is more of a sissy than a tough guy. However, it is worth adding that this add-on should be launched through Steam and not the desktop shortcut so that the achievements can be synchronized! The only thing was that the DLC and Apocalypse Weekend frequently crashed on my computer. I don't know if it's a Steam bug or if a patch would be helpful. I saved the game constantly, so it wasn't a major issue.

[i]This is not a game, it's a masterpiece. Even though it was released way back in 2003, it remains a worthy example of quality for many modern projects.[/i]

[h3][i]Story.[/i][/h3]
According to the plot, we need to live through a week in the life of an ordinary Dude (That's the name of our hero). But with each day, more and more absurd events will happen, from bank robberies and church explosions, to a full-scale apocalypse.

[h3][i]Gameplay.[/i][/h3]
The gameplay here is very diverse. We will interact with NPCs, shoot (a lot. very much) and.. just peacefully stand in lines :D What could go wrong? But when we have tons of explosives in our inventory, different types of guns, and mountains of drugs, simply standing and waiting won't be as fun as charging through.

[h3][i]Visuals.[/i][/h3]
The graphics here are very pleasant for games of that time. I adore it when the hitbox and collision of an object match its outer texture. It makes parkour easier and the worldview more accurate. And a bunch of small details, jokes, references, and a sea of satire don't allow the eye to stop enjoying.

[h3][i]Verdict.[/i][/h3]
As a result, this is so far one of the best games I have played. A phenomenally cruel and dynamic cocktail, but not from a bar, but a Molotov one. I'm glad there's DLC to extend the fun, as well as several other parts.
